section.name: INDEPENDENT STUDY: The Economic & Financial Crisis: Causes, Consequences & Policy Options

comments:
This course analyzes the causes and consequences of the current economic and financial crisis, and provides a forum for the discussion and analysis of the policy options available. The class consists of a well-structured series of interactive lectures by Wharton or Penn faculty specializing in the economic, financial, policy, and political aspects of the crisis, both in the U.S. and around the world.

Students consider this course “fabulous” and “incredibly stimulating.” It helped them to “have a better understanding of what is going on in the current economy.”

Students loved the “opportunity to listen to professors with whom [they] may have never taken a class.” Some of the “favorite” and “most memorable” include Siegel, Herring, Meyer, Gyourko, Useem, Schultz, and Mitchell. However, because a different professor conducts each lecture, the course “got redundant” with professors “repeating the same information class after class.”

Students criticized the “excessive workload,” especially for a pass/fail class worth only 0.5 units. Students would have liked to “explore topics outside of those presented in class” instead of simply “regurgitating the authors’ views.”
